title: Who will be appointed as the next leader of the Communist Party in Vietnam?
possible_answers: A new leader will not be appointed before 1 March 2021
correct_answer: A new leader will not be appointed before 1 March 2021
preds: As of January most news sources expected Nguyen Phu Trong, the country's current president, to be re-elected and serve a third term. This was recently confirmed, with party leaders unable to reach a consensus on a successor, leading to Trong's reappointment.

Nguyen Phu Trong has been reelected (despite not qualifying for serving a 3rd term). LIkely there will not be another election before Mar. 1 https://www.nytimes.com/2021/02/01/world/asia/vietnam-party-congress.html
The Communist Party in Vietnam chose to re-elect its leader Nguyen Phu Trong. He will now be serving his third term.
their current leader has been re-elected and no knowldge of a new one is in the works.
Nguyen Phu Trong has been re-elected and there have been no public statements to indicate this changing  https://www.globaltimes.cn/page/202101/1214497.shtml

There has been little to no mention of a new appointee to this position in recent media publications, especially considering the reelection of the incumbent on January 31st. (https://www.globaltimes.cn/page/202101/1214497.shtml) With the proximity of the end date of this prediction cycle, it is very unlikely that this will change.

Because:
- it didn't happen and there are few days left,
- nothing in medias to my knowledge indicates its return,
- there is a consensus of other forecasters since a few days
Seems to have been confirmed and not too long for something really weird to happen.
Asking for clarification. They did appoint the same guy but is not that act choosing a new leader? OR if not on list of choices is that not someone else?
If the same leader is appointed are they still the ‘next’ leader?  https://www.abc.net.au/news/2021-01-31/vietnams-ruling-communist-party-president-nguyen-phu-trong/13108026

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-vietnam-politics-congress/vietnams-communist-party-chief-nominated-for-re-election-state-media-idUSKBN29W0DS
same guy again, according to Reuters

If my understanding of the Note attached to the question is correct and this article - https://bit.ly/36BUQTR - of yesterday is correct, then the current incumbent has been reappointed with waivers on his health and age to head up the Communist Party for his third term. His appointment seems to be confirmed by this state issued press statement - https://bit.ly/3tqqvkX
I am not sure if this is the right bin for the current party leader being elected to a third term, but Trong was reelected. This one is going to hurt the Brier....

Reporting is that Nguyen Phu Trong was elected to a third term. https://www.nytimes.com/2021/02/01/world/asia/vietnam-party-congress.html
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-vietnam-politics-trong-idUSKBN2A006T
@bh4eh Have you looked at this and thought of entering the question? As far as I follow this up, there's some score to earn...

Stealing Ryan Beck's link - https://www.nytimes.com/2021/02/01/world/asia/vietnam-party-congress.html
Being a bit more conservative on risks of something else happening.

I think this can be closed now. But I guess the question wording is a bit ambiguous as to whether it's supposed to run all the way to March 1 in case Trong were to suddenly pass away and have to be replaced. I think the chances of that are minimal though. https://www.nytimes.com/2021/02/01/world/asia/vietnam-party-congress.html
Reacting to “leak” others have reported. Not taking it as certain especially given the seeming retraction. Nguyen Xuan Phuc level reflecting crowd.
NPC finishing a day early, so no pushback on Trong.
State media reports that Nguyen Phu Trong was nominated for a third term. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-vietnam-politics-congress-idUSKBN29W0DS
The lack of any denial of the leaks seems telling, increasing Trong forecast
Others seem to be favoring Trong serving another term as resolving as a new leader not being appointed, so I'll favor that one for now.

According to this it was leaked that Trong will remain leader for another term. I don't know if that qualifies as a new leader not being appointed or someone else. https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-55728575

Nguyen Phu Trong appears likely to remain in office. Therefore, I am forecasting that a new leader will not be appointed before 1 March. https://www.dw.com/en/vietnam-communist-party-congress-picks-new-leadership/a-56332574
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-vietnam-politics-congress-idUSKBN29U0DA
Seems to be some noise that Trong came out on top at the NPC, but not entirely sure if that means he will stay or Vuong got the vote.
Still looks like he will be the next leader.

Two more recent articles which seem to suggest that Vuong may be the favorite, but also that he may be unpopular. But one of them also throws another name in, Lich, who I haven't seen mentioned but the article suggests he may be in the running. It also brings up the fact that all of these candidates are over 65 and would have to be granted an exemption (which sounds pretty easy so not a deal breaker at all). Based on these articles I'm reducing confidence even further, distributing some to the someone else category and Ngan, and keeping Vuong as slightly favored over Phuc. https://asiatimes.com/2021/01/battle-lines-drawn-for-vietnams-party-congress/ https://thediplomat.com/2021/01/vietnams-13th-congress-institutional-resilience-or-institutional-decay/

The more I read on this, the less sure the political commentators seem to be about what is likely to happen, and one early blogpost seems to have decided the narrative. So re-weighting Phuc into Truong and a compromise candidate.
Truong keeps the party secretary position according to the depths of unsubstantiated Twitter rumor and "translate tweet."

Commentary seems to be this will be competitive and lots of contenders. Would have been close to uniform across the 3 major candidates and “no change”. Moved away from this given the crowd forecast. Would not want to be this swayed by the consensus, but do not know a lot about this and internet sources all seem quite out of date.

I need to see more commentary on this but based on this article I'm reducing confidence in Phuc. I haven't seen anything supporting the heavy crowd confidence on Phuc other than a few suggestions in articles that he may be the favorite. Sounds like it could be a close race between Phuc and Vuong, and the main reason to think it might not be Vuong is because he didn't win it already at the earlier party event. https://asia.nikkei.com/Politics/Vietnam-s-leader-wants-a-successor-tough-on-corruption

Per some forecasters, it’s difficult to know for certain given a certain opaqueness... this doesn’t clear it up but FYI from Economist 
“In a political set-up that shuns personality, let alone personality cults, Nguyen Xuan Phuc, prime minister of Vietnam and one of the favourites to take over as general secretary of the Communist Party, fits the bill to a tee. A seasoned administrator with a background in management studies, he has shown a steady hand, not least in his effective handling of covid-19—aided by a healthy distrust of China’s initial reassurances. Still, his lack of experience in the propaganda side of national leadership could be costly. His focus will be to tackle an entrenched system of back-scratching among politicians and business leaders, sometimes crossing the line into corruption, which is off-putting to foreign investors. The new team will also need to find an accommodation with China on territory the two countries dispute in the South China Sea.“

I think I was probably too influenced by the crowd on my initial estimate, there doesn't seem to be any reason to give Phuc a bigger than even chance, especially as there seems to be question marks as to whether or not he may actually want to continue as prime minister. So going from 8/66/20/4/2 to 15/50/24/9/2

Tinkering based on reports that; - the outcome of the VCP Congress is widely perceived in Hanoi to be very “competitive” and “unpredictable,” (1);
- it remains to be seen whether Trong will keep his post as the party’s general secretary (1); and
- Phuc is a strong candidate and is likely to put his hand up based on his year, however Vuong aligns with General Secetary Trong's ideology. (2)
- Ngan is current chair of the National Assembly and is widely expected to be succeeded by Truong Thi Mai, the head of the Mass Mobilisation Commission. The National Assembly chair is the least powerful of the four top positions, but Trong himself held that role from 2006-2011. (3) 1. https://thediplomat.com/2020/12/vietnams-balancing-act-between-biden-and-trump/
2. https://thediplomat.com/2020/12/vietnam-party-conclave-readies-key-personnel-appointments/
3. https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-vietnam-politics-candidates/factbox-potential-candidates-for-vietnams-leadership-transition-idUKKBN28O0KN
Holding strong on the most likely candidate.
No idea. So going with the flow. But saving 1% for 'Someone Else'. On the basis of 'never say never'.
Ngo Xuan Lich - current Defense Minister will become the next leader of Communist Party as his closer relation with China and in the effort to keep military under the Party control
Following the crowd a bit. Though I genuinely have no idea why the crowd is so confident on Phuc, as the articles said Vuong is favored by the current party leader.

If the 11th National Congress can serve as a baseline (the 12th NC is less useful as the incumbent was re-electable), then the candidate that won was supposedly the candidate that was expected (https://www.taiwannews.com.tw/en/news/1490721), so maybe that is why the crowd forecast is so one-sided. However, with so few information sources, and Trong apparently supporting Vuong, I am not sure how one can be so confident.
The Diplomat suggests that Trong will remain as the party leader.  https://thediplomat.com/2016/01/who-will-lead-vietnam/

I weighted the advantage of Vuong having the support of Trong too much, sounds like he's not favored as a replacement and Phuc is the favorite. Switching their probabilities. https://www.asiasentinel.com/p/vietnam-wrestles-to-install-new-leadership

Based on the last Diplomat article it seems Vuong is sort of set up as successor which to me makes him a strong favorite. Phuc sounds like a strong possibility as well. For now setting Vuong as favorite followed by Phuc until I do more research.
reviewed crowd forecast, forecast with comments, and went slightly higher  than the recent ones.  First estimate on this topic.  Will review periodically

Given how little I know and just reading the articles, it seems Phuc is the favorite, but there is a chance for either Vuong or Ngan.  Going to go lighter on the probabilities (regress more to the mean) than the group's consensus.

I can't see how this system has any difference to the rest of the world in the assessment of leader's based on Covid responses. Reviewing the links put up by @willk and @yvesManchot I struggle to see the candidate who is being credited for a competent navigation of the pandemic not getting what they want, but darker forces can always intervene. Which is pretty much how the Diplomat described it, "Tran Quoc Vuong, Trong’s right-hand man and current executive secretary of the Central Committee Secretariat, is the front-runner if his mentor gets his way in the coming months. But the current prime minister, Nguyen Xuan Phuc, is many pundits’ odds-on favorite to take the Party chief post. He has significantly improved Hanoi’s competency over the last four years and has won much applause for his handling of the COVID-19 pandemic, in which Vietnam managed to record no deaths until late July."
Based on this article and accompanying analysis: https://thediplomat.com/2020/09/three-horse-race-for-vietnams-next-communist-party-chief/

Nguyễn Xuân Phúc appears to be the slight favorite based on the linked articles and I believe that a recency bias will favor him. His improvement of Hanoi's competency and handling of COVID will be on everyone's minds. With less info on Trần Quốc Vượng, other than being the right-hand man of the current General Secretary, I can't discount his chances too much. Nguyễn Thị Kim Ngân is a long shot, but not impossible if the Party wants to further promote equality and elect someone less divisive.

Based on current projections and regional dynamics across party positions, largely contingent on whether the party chief and "President" roles remain combined at this next party congress.
https://www.iseas.edu.sg/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/ISEAS_Perspective_2020_84.pdf

Looks to me like Nguyễn Xuân Phúc is the clear front runner with the support needed to win. Will update as new info comes out.  https://www.asiasentinel.com/p/vietnam-wrestles-to-install-new-leadership

Been a long time since I had to know about this stuff, but things must have changed rather a lot for anyone to be considered a sure-fire winner at this point in the festivities.  Nguyen Xuan Phuc is the clear front-runner just now, though.   This should be less bourbon-intensive than the recent US carryings-on--although less public, so harder to divine what's going on.
I get it that Mr. Phuc is #1 but I am not sure that even Vietnamese nationals would have such a high degree of confidence on such an opaque process. Therefore coming in a little lower than the crowd

Vietnam Wrestles to Install New Leadership.

This time the battle is unlikely to spill into the public domain, and it is strongly rumored that in place of Trong's man Tran Quoc Vuong, incumbent Prime Minister Nguyen Xuan Phuc (above) already commands the support of most Central Committee members (Para 6).
